Award.AwardTitle: REU Site in Interdisciplinary Materials Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL PART: The REU Site at Southern Illinois University Carbondale will provide research opportunities for an average of 14 undergraduates per year (including 2 supported internally) for a 9 week period each summer. Students will be involved in interdisciplinary projects in the broadly defined area of materials research. Inclusion of faculty mentors from various disciplines (Chemistry, Physics, Engineering, Microbiology, and the Materials Technology Center) will enable the REU students to develop skills needed to excel in both academic and industrial research environments, where interdisciplinary teams are standard and researchers must communicate effectively across disciplines. Students will also be required to think about the application of their research to new technologies and the manufacturing of new devices, and they will have the opportunity to present their results to a diverse audience. Primary goals of the site include: (1) creating a positive image of science and engineering as a career choice, (2) providing a nurturing environment and instilling a sense of confidence in the art of discussing and practicing science, (3) improving the participants' oral and written communication skills, (4) teaching of basic research tools, including literature searches and the operation of modern instrumentation, (5) fostering a collaborative teamwork approach to research, and (6) increasing the number of domestic students, especially those from underrepresented groups, who choose to pursue STEM careers. A detailed assessment plan will evaluate the success of the activity.

TECHNICAL PART: The Site will recruit primarily from 2 and 4-year institutions residing in neighboring states or the Mississippi Delta region, and from those institutions with traditionally high enrollments of students from underrepresented groups. Students participating in the Site will learn to network with other scientists and engineers through various social activities including weekly lunches with faculty mentors and weekend trips to cultural, industrial, and recreational locations. The available mentored research projects promise to be excellent training grounds for working in materials and related fields. Students will be exposed to a variety of transformative projects at the forefront of science and engineering, including: (1) studies related to the synthesis of advanced functional materials (graphene, two-dimensional layered chalcogenides, metal oxide nanowires and functionalized structures, inorganic heterostructures, nanocomposites, nanoscale catalysts, novel electron-accepting materials, electrospun nanofibers, etc.), (2) materials characterization (via electron microscopies, solid- and solution-state nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, low-temperature electronic, optical/magnetic transport measurements, ultraviolet/visible/infrared spectroscopies, etc.), (3) theoretical/computational studies (wherein students will learn how to study materials via density functional theory calculations, molecular dynamics simulations, etc.), and (4) materials applications varying from energy storage and photovoltaics, to biosensors and nanoparticle-based antigen-delivery vehicles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The demands of industrial and academic research drive the development of improved ways to train students. It is not uncommon to find teams of researchers with diverse interdisciplinary backgrounds that are working together to solve a common problem. Indeed, this is becoming the norm in both industrial and academic laboratories, particularly for the development and application of new materials. The activities undertaken in this NSF-REU program is to provide such interdisciplinary research and training  activities in the field of Materials Science and drew its strength from several core discipline such as Chemistry, Physics, Electrical Engineering, Computing etc. Delivering the understanding of basic science as well as the impact of this understanding in developing applications (ranging from nano-electronics to biofuels using novel materials)--to a generation of young students in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) discipline--was one of the principle foci of the program.

The Broader Impacts of this REU Site were manifold as well. Through this program we were able to  enable the participation of undergraduate students?particularly those from underrepresented groups and 2-/4-year institutions with little or no major research infrastructure or opportunities?in mentored research. We were able to encourage the participants to choose STEM-based career paths, gave opportunities for the broad dissemination of scientific results via student-co-authored technical publications and conference presentations and provided interdisciplinary training for next generation students/workforce. Some of these specific outcomes are summarized below. 

Recruitment Outcomes: For our most recent three-year cycle (plus one year of NCE), ~45% (26) were female, ~52% (30) were male, and ~3% (2) were gender-non-binary. Over 29% were from underrepresented minority groups, a number that grows to over 41% when other types of underrepresented students are included (e.g. female physicists/engineers). Over 64% of participants were from our targeted institutions in the region (IL, IN, MO, KY, WI, IA, & TN), select HBCUs, high minority-enrollment institutions, and junior colleges (from within and outside this targeted region); nevertheless, the relatively large number of applicants from outside our list of targeted schools likely indicates that our REU program is being proactively sought out by students using the internet.

The recruitment outcomes for the past 13 years and their assessment in terms of our Program?s original goals may be found in Figure 1. Overall, we are pleased with the process and results of the recruitment during these years of our NSF-REU program. The numbers of strong, qualified candidates was more than sufficient for us to routinely construct an excellent cohort of participants. Indeed, for the candidates who accepted our offer (yield generally >50%), the numbers of participants who were from underrepresented groups, female participants, external participants, participants from targeted schools / regions, and students from non-PhD granting schools exceeded our goals in most cases and nearly met our goals in most of the remaining cases.

Assessment of Student Outcomes. The consensus of the participating faculty was that the recruited students were high quality and possessed great potential as future scientists and researchers (at least according to all feedback received by the PI/Co-PI. All participants successfully completed their oral presentation, their poster and poster presentation, and final research report, and completed (e.g. instrumentation) training associated with their respective projects. However, arguably the most important outcome, in our opinion, from this program so far is that over 78% of our REU alumni (this summer sampling participant years 2009-2017) are on STEM career tracks, including 30 currently enrolled in science/engineering grad school, and 61 that have employment in STEM fields) (Fig. 2). We also not that 9 of the participants who have gone onto graduate school have chosen graduate programs here at SIUC?in addition to 3 junior-college transfers into our undergraduate program.  So, far according to our knowledge we have at least 10 PhD REU alums.

Research Outcomes. While all REU participants presented their research in poster form at our annual summer undergraduate research symposium (this year well-attended by over 100 other scientists and students) and summarize their work in the final written report, our REU program also actively encourages its participants to participate in the wide public dissemination of their research results, and towards this end provides financial support for attending and presenting their work at research conferences across the country. We can report 5 publications, 12 conference presentations and 1 patent filed in 2018 (in addition to 50 publications, 1 patent filed, and 82 total conference presentations from the previous cycles). This brings the scholarly outcome of the REU program to date (2006-2018) to 55 publications, 94 conference presentations and 2 patent applications filed. A large number (>45 different) REU participants have been listed as co-authors and/or co-presenters so far in the above mentions publications/presentations/patents (2006-2018).
